div1.p: Albertini takes issue with Reed's statement that the Board of Havana experts considered Finlay's theory wild. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Letter from A. Diaz Albertini to Albert E. Truby and Jefferson Randolph Kean, September 7, 1944
div1.opener:
DR. A. DIAZ ALBERTINI
AV. DE BRUSELAS 20, REP. KOHLY, MARIANAO
TEL. FO-2592
-----
CONSULTAS EN HABANA NO. 7
DE 4 A 6
---
Please return.
A.E.T.
Cuba
Havana, Sept. 7,
1944
Brigadier General
Albert E. Truby
c/o General J.R. Kean
2804 N. Street
Georgetown, Was
Dear General:
div1.p:
In your intrusting recent book
tittled “Memoir of Walter Reed” The Yellow Fever
Episode, and in the Fig. 26, which follows Page
(156)
AET
Truby
56, it seems that on October 10th, 1900, from the
Columbia Barracks, Quemados, Walter Reed wrote
the following to his wife: “.... The case is a
beautiful one, and will be seen by the Board of
Havana Experts, to-day, all of whom, except Finlay
consider the theory a wild one!

As I am the only living member of
that Commission I am obliged to express to you,
with all respect which the memory of that great
man of science, and at the same time a great
soldier, imposes, my inconformity with such an
assertion, not only in that which refers to me,
but also to my fellow workers no longer living:
Drs. Major Gorgas and Juan Guiteras.

I do not understand how it happened
that the then Major Reed should have thought of
us in the erroneous judgement that is attributed
to us. Surely, the rapidity with which the
happenings were developing, the impression of
the great discover of Carlos Finlay and the cons-
tant tention of the very valuable work which he
DR. A. DIAZ ALBERTINI
AV. DE BRUSELAS 20, REP. KOHLY, MARIANAO
TEL. FO-2592
-----
CONSULTAS EN HABANA NO. 7
DE 4 A 6
---
had to direct, were influencing factors leading
to the mistaken judgement cited above.

You will understand, Mr. General, the
importance that this point has for me, not so much
for that which concerns me personally, as for the
references which are made to my two illustrious
companions.

If it is not requesting too much of you,
permit me to ask that you publish the contents of
this letter in some scientific magazine of your
great country, which we consider not only as our
friend but as our brother.
